citations.narrative:
The two large rabbit enclosures, which are composed of solid floors, have excessive accumulations of rabbit feces
present on the floors. These accumulations appear to be several days worth and it covers a significant amount of the floor
space. These enclosures must be cleaned to remove said accumulations and cleaned on a more frequent basis to
prevent such large accumulations.
Primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs and other debris by periodic cleaning.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 19, 2025

The two chinchilla enclosures each have wooden shelves that have been chewed to the extent where the shelves are in
disrepair. These shelves and the damaged edges could cause harm to the chinchillas housed therein. Damaged shelving
should be repaired or replaced to protect the chinchillas from injury and to maintain structural strength.
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor
and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals
from injury and to contain the animals.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 25, 2025

The damaged shelves and floors on the two chinchilla enclosures have large accumulations of feces present. The
accumulations appear to be days worth. Facility must clean these accumulations and removed on a more frequent basis
to prevent contamination and such accumulations.
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals
contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors.
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 19, 2025

citations.desc: Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being.
citations.narrative:
The documented program of environmental enhancement for birds has still not been completed. This documented plan, to
promote the psychological well-being of birds, should be reviewed and approved by the attending veterinarian. Facility
must document and follow a bird enrichment plan for the exhibit birds present.
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the
attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides.
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee.
n

narrative:
3.56(a)(1) 
   
Sanitation. 
The two large rabbit enclosures, which are composed of solid floors, have excessive accumulations of rabbit feces 
present on the floors. These accumulations appear to be several days worth and it covers a significant amount of the floor 
space. These enclosures must be cleaned to remove said accumulations and cleaned on a more frequent basis to 
prevent such large accumulations. 
 
Primary enclosures shall be kept reasonably free of excreta, hair, cobwebs and other debris by periodic cleaning.  
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 19, 2025 
3.125(a) 
   
Facilities, general. 
The two chinchilla enclosures each have wooden shelves that have been chewed to the extent where the shelves are in 
disrepair. These shelves and the damaged edges could cause harm to the chinchillas housed therein. Damaged shelving 
should be repaired or replaced to protect the chinchillas from injury and to maintain structural strength. 
 
The facility must be constructed of such material and of such strength as appropriate for the animals involved. The indoor 
and outdoor housing facilities shall be structurally sound and shall be maintained in good repair to protect the animals 
from injury and to contain the animals. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 25, 2025 
3.131(a) 
   
Sanitation. 
The damaged shelves and floors on the two chinchilla enclosures have large accumulations of feces present. The 
accumulations appear to be days worth. Facility must clean these accumulations and removed on a more frequent basis 
to prevent contamination and such accumulations. 
 
Excreta shall be removed from primary enclosures as often as necessary to prevent contamination of the animals

contained therein and to minimize disease hazards and to reduce odors. 
 
TO BE CORRECTED BY: FEBRUARY 19, 2025 
3.154  Repeat
   
Environment enhancement to promote psychological well-being. 
The documented program of environmental enhancement for birds has still not been completed. This documented plan, to 
promote the psychological well-being of birds, should be reviewed and approved by the attending veterinarian. Facility 
must document and follow a bird enrichment plan for the exhibit birds present. 
 
Dealers, exhibitors, and research facilities must develop, document, and follow a species-appropriate plan for 
environment enhancement adequate to promote the psychological well-being of birds. The plan must be approved by the 
attending veterinarian and must be in accordance with the regulations in this subpart and with currently accepted 
professional standards as cited in appropriate professional journals or reference guides. 
 
This inspection and exit briefing were conducted with the licensee.
